awd_titl_txt: Plasticity, Phase Transformations, and their Interaction under High Pressure in Silicon
awd_abstract_narration:
The interaction between crystalline phase transformations and permanent plastic deformation under high pressure in materials is broadly found in several technological applications; however, knowledge of this phenomenon is scarce because of the specialized equipment needed to observe it. This award fills the gap by supporting an integrated experimental, theoretical, and computational study of this interaction in silicon. Silicon is chosen as a representative material because it exhibits numerous types of phase transformations and is widely used in electronics and micro-electromechanical systems, as well as solar cells. The knowledge gained on the fundamental aspects of phase transformation-plasticity interaction under high pressure will also have broader implications on the quantitative modeling and optimization of surface processes, such as polishing, turning, and scratching, for brittle semiconductors and ceramics. As part of the project, there will be opportunities to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students through special courses and research, parts of which will be conducted at the Argonne National Laboratory, with an emphasis on underrepresented students.

The objective of this research is to investigate the effect of plastic flow on phase transformation under high pressure in silicon. Coupled in situ high-throughput experiments and modeling will yield quantitative characterization and understanding of how plastic straining drastically reduces the transformation pressure, promotes the formation of novel phases, retains high-pressure phases at ambient pressure, and changes transformation paths between different phases. Silicon samples will be compressed and sheared in a rotational diamond anvil cell. Synchrotron X-ray diffraction and absorption, Raman spectroscopy, and displacement measurements will be used for in-situ diagnostics of the deformation and transformation processes. A microscale phase field approach for coupled phase transformations and localized shear bands (e.g., due to dislocation pileups) will be developed and used to study the interplay between multiple phase transformations and mechanisms of plasticity in single grains and polycrystalline aggregates. Phase transformation criteria, strain-controlled kinetic equations, and the pressure- and plastic strain-dependent yield strengths of all phases and phase mixtures will be obtained from the experiments and incorporated in a macroscale phenomenological model. This model will be used in the finite element simulations of deformation-transformation processes in diamond anvils. A search for new phases will also be performed as an application of the computational framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to conduct the first coupled in situ high-throughput experimental, theoretical, and computational two-scale study of stress and strain tensor fields, plastic flow, and strain-induced phase transformations (PTs) in Si under high pressure and large plastic deformation in a diamond anvil cell (DAC) and torsion in rotational DAC (RDAC).

Intellectual Merit:

  1. The following breakthrough experimental results are obtained.

(a)   For nano-Si, plastic straining reduces Si-I→II PT pressure from 16.2 GPa (hydrostatic) to 0.3 GPa, i.e., by 54 times! This pressure is 35 times lower than the phase equilibrium pressure!

(b)  For PT Si-I→II, the minimum pressure for strain-induced PT p_ep= 0.3 GPa in 100 nm Si is the same for compression in DAC and torsion in RDAC. Since the plastic strain tensor and its path are very different for compression and torsion, p_ep is independent of the plastic strain tensor and its path. This rule reveals that the physics of strain-induced PTs under compression in DAC and torsion in RDAC do not differ fundamentally, and strain-induced PTs can also be studied in DAC.

(c)   The strain-induced PT Si-I→Si-III initiates at 0.6 GPa for 100 nm Si, and PT Si-I→Si-II starts at 4.9 GPa for 30 nm Si, but both do not occur under hydrostatic loading for these particles.

(d)   For 100 nm Si, under torsion, PT occurs in the sequence Si-I→I+II→I+II+III, in contrast to different PT sequences suggested in ex-situ studies in the previous literature.

(e)   The coexistence of four phases, Si-I, Si-II, Si-III, and Si-XI, under torsion of 100 nm Si, was observed for the first time.

(f)    Based on gained understanding, we resolved long-standing puzzles, namely, retained Si-II at ambient pressure and obtained reverse Si-II→Si-I PT, demonstrating the possibilities of manipulating different synthetic paths.

(g)   We recovered single-phase nano-Si-III in the entire region r ≤ 90 microns and nanocomposite of two semiconducting phases Si-I+III after plastic deformation of 100 nm Si in DAC, which was never done before. Nano Si-III has potential applications in electronics but was obtained by high-pressure torsion at 24 GPa and 10 anvil turns.

2. A new theory is developed that correlates the grain-size dependence of p_ep and the yield strength (Hall-Petch relationship).  It is confirmed experimentally for  Si-I→Si-II PT.

3. We developed a coupled analytical-computational-experimental approach to determine material deformational and transformational properties and stress and plastic strain tensor fields in DAC.

4. A new unprecedented Si-II nanostructure was discovered by combining molecular dynamics, crystallographic theory, generalized for strained crystals, and in-situ real-time Laue XRD.

5. We developed a new finite-strain phase field approach (PFA) for multivariant martensitic PTs with stress-dependent effective thresholds at the microscale and applied it for simulations of Si-I→Si-II PT in a single and polycrystal.

6. New scale-free PFA for interaction between PT and dislocation pileups at small strains is developed and applied to a bicrystal and polycrystalline 2D sample, proving drastic reduction in PT pressure due to dislocation pileups. In addition, multiphase PFAs for PTs at the nanoscale,  fracture with surface stresses, and interaction of fracture and PTs are developed.

8. Using the concurrent-atomistic-continuum approach, we received the first atomistic proof of the strong reduction in PT pressure due to dislocation pileup.  

9. Using molecular dynamics, we found and rationalized analytically how the high-velocity dislocation in Si-I can propagate under stresses much below the Peierls stress, which may promote the formation of pileup and PT under dynamic loading. 

10. Fifth-order elastic energy is found using the density functional theory results. It describes stress-strain curves and instabilities leading to Si-I → Si-II PT at complex loading.

Broad Impacts: Three PhD students worked on the project, one graduated and one passed the preliminary exam. Three post-docs, seven undergraduate US students (supported by REU supplement, four among them are female and one under-represented), and six alumni have worked on the project. Two PhD students worked as interns at Argonne National Laboratory supported by INTERN supplements and Argonne Laboratory. The PI developed and taught a new research-oriented graduate class, "High-pressure mechanics and phase transformations," and significantly updated his research-oriented graduate classes "Phase Transformations in Elastic Materials," "Micromechanics of structural changes in materials," and "Continuum Mechanochemistry." All classes included many results obtained in this project and acquaintance with PI's high pressure-shear lab. Results of the project have been disseminated through 25 journal publications in highly-ranked journals (including 3 papers in Nature Communications, 7 in Acta Materials, 2 in PRB, 2 in Materials Research Letters, as well as in npj Computational Materials, Carbon, International J. Plasticity, J. Mech. Phys. Solids, Int. J. Eng. Sci., J. Alloys and Compounds, etc.; 3 invited review papers), 79 conference talks (including 4 plenary/semi-plenary lectures and 19 keynote and invited talks), and 12 invited seminars. The PI co-organized two symposia on the topic of the project.

 


Last Modified: 05/26/2024
Modified by: Valery I Levitas

Images (1 of )
  • Results are obtained using a developed scale-free phase filed approach. Dislocation pileups significantly reduce phase transformation pressure.
    Ehsan Esfahani and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    Evolution of the dislocation bands and high-pressure phase regions (red) under compression and increasing shear γ in a polycrystalline aggregate.
  • Left: Crystal lattice instability conditions for Si-I to Si-II. Right: The true shear stress-strain curves for Si-I.
    Hao Chen, Nikolai Zarkevich, and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    Comparison between density functional theory (DFT) simulations and results from the developed fifth-order elastic potential under general complex loadings.
  • Transparent view of PTs showing regions with the maximum value of all three crystallographic variants (red c1 = 1 and blue and yellow c2 = c3 = 0.3) for uniaxial compressive loading of a Si (001) single crystal.
    Hamed Babaei and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    Multivariant martensitic microstructure evolution during Si I-Si II phase transformation obtained with a scale-free phase field approach.
  • Molecular dynamics simulations (left) and in-situ real-time Laue x-ray diffraction (right).
    Hao Chen, Dmitry Popov, and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    New nanostructure discovered during Si-I to Si-II phase transformation.
  • Obtained variation of the minimum pressure for plastic strain-induced phase transformation is very unexpected because under hydrostatic loading, phase transformation pressure increases with particle size reduction.
    Sorb Yesudhas and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    Schematics of RDAC and a correlation between the particle size's direct and inverse Hall-Petch effect on yield strength and pressure for strain-induced phase transformation.
  • The initiation of phase transformation pressures and anvil rotation angles (for RDAC) are shown above the arrows. The pressure transmitting medium (PTM) and gasket types (stainless steel (S.S.) and copper Cu) used in the experiment are shown on the right side of the figure.
    Sorb Yesudhas and Valery Levitas
    Copyrighted
    Valery I Levitas
    Summary of a sequence of phase transformations in Si with different particle sizes under hydrostatic and non-hydrostatic (plastic) compressions and torsion inside RDAC.
por.por_txt_cntn:
The goal of the project is to conduct the first coupled in situ high-throughput experimental, theoretical, and computational two-scale study of stress and strain tensor fields, plastic flow, and strain-induced phase transformations (PTs) in Si under high pressure and large plastic deformation in a diamond anvil cell (DAC) and torsion in rotational DAC (RDAC).


Intellectual Merit:

The following breakthrough experimental results are obtained.



(a) For nano-Si, plastic straining reduces Si-III PT pressure from 16.2 GPa (hydrostatic) to 0.3 GPa, i.e., by 54 times! This pressure is 35 times lower than the phase equilibrium pressure!


(b) For PT Si-III, the minimum pressure for strain-induced PT p_ep= 0.3 GPa in 100 nm Si is the same for compression in DAC and torsion in RDAC. Since the plastic strain tensor and its path are very different for compression and torsion, p_epis independent of the plastic strain tensor and its path. This rule reveals that the physics of strain-induced PTs under compression in DAC and torsion in RDAC do not differ fundamentally, and strain-induced PTs can also be studied in DAC.


(c) The strain-induced PT Si-ISi-III initiates at 0.6 GPa for 100 nm Si, and PT Si-ISi-II starts at 4.9 GPa for 30 nm Si, but both do not occur under hydrostatic loading for these particles.


(d) For 100 nm Si, under torsion, PT occurs in the sequence Si-II+III+II+III, in contrast to different PT sequences suggested in ex-situ studies in the previous literature.


(e) The coexistence of four phases, Si-I, Si-II, Si-III, and Si-XI, under torsion of 100 nm Si, was observed for the first time.


(f) Based on gained understanding, we resolved long-standing puzzles, namely, retained Si-II at ambient pressure and obtained reverse Si-IISi-I PT, demonstrating the possibilities of manipulating different synthetic paths.


(g) We recovered single-phase nano-Si-III in the entire region r  90 microns and nanocomposite of two semiconducting phases Si-I+III after plastic deformation of 100 nm Si in DAC, which was never done before. Nano Si-III has potential applications in electronics but was obtained by high-pressure torsion at 24 GPa and 10 anvil turns.


2. A new theory is developed that correlates the grain-size dependence of p_ep and the yield strength (Hall-Petch relationship). It is confirmed experimentally for Si-ISi-II PT.


3. We developed a coupled analytical-computational-experimental approach to determine material deformational and transformational properties and stress and plastic strain tensor fields in DAC.


4. A new unprecedented Si-II nanostructure was discovered by combining molecular dynamics, crystallographic theory, generalized for strained crystals, and in-situ real-time Laue XRD.


5. We developed a newfinite-strain phase field approach (PFA) formultivariant martensitic PTs with stress-dependent effective thresholds at the microscale and applied it for simulations of Si-ISi-II PT in a single and polycrystal.


6. New scale-free PFA for interaction between PT and dislocation pileups at small strains is developed and applied to a bicrystal and polycrystalline 2D sample, proving drastic reduction in PT pressure due to dislocation pileups. In addition, multiphase PFAs for PTs at the nanoscale, fracture with surface stresses, and interaction of fracture and PTs are developed.


8. Using the concurrent-atomistic-continuum approach, we received the first atomistic proof of the strong reduction in PT pressure due to dislocation pileup.


9. Using molecular dynamics, we found and rationalized analytically how the high-velocity dislocation in Si-I can propagate under stresses much below the Peierls stress, which may promote the formation of pileup and PT under dynamic loading.


10. Fifth-order elastic energy is found using the density functional theory results. It describes stress-strain curves and instabilities leading to Si-I  Si-II PT at complex loading.


Broad Impacts: Three PhD students worked on the project, one graduated and one passed the preliminary exam. Three post-docs, seven undergraduate US students (supported by REU supplement, four among them are female and one under-represented), and six alumni have worked on the project. Two PhD students worked as interns at Argonne National Laboratory supported by INTERN supplements and Argonne Laboratory. The PI developed and taught a new research-oriented graduate class, "High-pressure mechanics and phase transformations," and significantly updated his research-oriented graduate classes "Phase Transformations in Elastic Materials," "Micromechanics of structural changes in materials," and "Continuum Mechanochemistry." All classes included many results obtained in this project and acquaintance with PI's high pressure-shear lab. Results of the project have been disseminated through 25 journal publications in highly-ranked journals (including 3 papers in Nature Communications, 7 in Acta Materials, 2 in PRB, 2 in Materials Research Letters, as well as in npj Computational Materials, Carbon, International J. Plasticity, J. Mech. Phys. Solids, Int. J. Eng. Sci., J. Alloys and Compounds, etc.; 3 invited review papers), 79 conference talks (including 4 plenary/semi-plenary lectures and 19 keynote and invited talks), and 12 invited seminars. The PI co-organized two symposia on the topic of the project.
